The legalisation of marijuana: safety and psychology

11/10/2022

Legalising marijuana will allow for safer consumption, while also removing the allure of its use

Image by Sebastian Dooris

By Raphael Henry

There is a prominent reverse psychology when it comes to the law. If you are told not to do something, human nature is often to do the opposite. There is a small glimmer in the back of the mind, provoking us to do the contrary. Perhaps we just enjoy being antithetical, simply because we can. Others label the sensation â€˜intrusive thoughtsâ€™: the urge to impulsively do what you logically know you probably shouldn't.

This psychology can be applied to the consumption of illegal substances. In the UK cannabis is currently a Class B illegal drug. With a maximum penalty of 5 years in prison for possession and fourteen years for supply and production, the drug hardly has light consequences in the eyes of the law. Despite society's generally relaxed attitude toward cannabis, and its extensive use for both recreational and medical purposes, it is not tolerated legally.

So why is cannabis illegal? Take alcohol as an example. Another intoxicating substance, it results in significant decreases in motor skills, altered behaviour and memory loss. Simply put, it is a poison.

Yet culturally, we thrive on the idea of alcohol. How often do you hear someone say, â€˜I could really do with a pintâ€™? Probably more than you hear people comment on how much they would enjoy a joint. Alcohol is popular, and its consumption is widely socially acceptable. Given that alcohol has well-known short and long-term damaging effects, how is it still legal when cannabis is not?

A point to remark upon is that the UKâ€™s views are not echoed elsewhere across the globe, with 30 countries legalising recreational use of cannabis, and many more for medicinal purposes. Countries such as the Netherlands and Canada are well known for their free and open usage of marijuana.

So what are the benefits of making a class B drug as socially acceptable as alcohol? The most crucial reason is safety. By legalising substances, automatically you are regulating the whole production line, gaining greater clarity on the substances' contents. In the Netherlands, you must have a licence to sell cannabis, in much the same way as you must own a licence to sell alcohol in the UK. Despite the previously mentioned negative effects on physical health, it is a huge positive that when we buy alcohol from a shop or a pub, we know exactly what the contents of it are.

The same cannot be said for illegal drugs. Without the proper regulations, it is not in the interest of providers to consider safety, often filling substances with whatever is cheapest. This is shown in Germanyâ€™s new market of synthetic cannabis, distributed across Europe. Plants are sprayed and laced to make it stronger and more addictive, boosting sales and lowering production prices, yet creating an incredibly dangerous substance for recreational use in the process.

Not only does legalisation create safer drugs, it also cuts down usage. Returning to reverse psychology, once the novelty and stigma is removed, fewer people find it desirable to consume.

Take the example of Portugal. The country experienced a significant rise in drug use during the 1980s, which lasted over two decades. At its peak, one-tenth of the population was addicted to heroin. Alvaro Pereira, a family doctor working in southern Portugal who was at the forefront of tackling the crisis, proposed addressing this situation in a remarkable way: by legalising almost everything. With heroin and cannabis completely legal, Portugal instead focused on hospitalisation and the health of individuals. This made drug use safer and communication of the problem far more open. Pereira witnessed dramatic drops in problematic drug use, HIV and hepatitis infection rates, overdose deaths and drug-related crime. By legalising these substances, people are able to get the help they need and engage in safer drug consumption.

Meanwhile France have introduced similar, though less extreme, measures. Last month, their government authorised the cultivation of cannabis for medicinal purposes. Not only does this allow for significant medical developments, but encourages much safer use, as those who require the drug don't have to rely on unreliable strains from illegal dealers.

Circling back to the psychological side of legalisation, I believe that the forbidden nature of drug use plays a hugely significant part in its appeal. There is an appeal for many, particularly in the student and younger population, in the idea of breaking the law. Drug use at university trumps almost any other population demographic, with just under 50 percent of students reporting that they used marijuana in 2020. The illegality of drugs causes people to seek them out in order to satisfy a rebellious streak. One finds that, once restrictions are removed and a society of free use is normalised, the appeal of these substances disappears. This philosophy is echoed in many things, especially parenting. Give a child access to sweets their whole life and they will never have a burning desire to seek them out. Restrict access, and they will make it their mission to consume as much as is humanly possible.

So, I return to my question: what is it about cannabis which makes it illegal? In reality, the substance is no worse for you than alcohol (which also used to be illegal in the early 20th century). Bans on cannabis originated in the USA, with Richard Nixonâ€™s effort to win the election and keep the White House. Two groups strongly opposed his Presidency: hippies and black people. Unable to make it illegal to be against the Vietnam War or to be black, the Nixon campaign instead associated illegal drugs and drug-related crime and violence with these two groups, weakening them and turning public opinion against them.

Nixonâ€™s opinions spread across to Europe, similarly hardening the stance in those countries. Europe once had a more lenient attitude to cannabis use, with a government commission in the 1970s recommending that marijuana use should not be criminalised and that it posed very little threat to the individual. In this way, stigma around cannabis spread, making rules harsher today than they perhaps would've been otherwise.

If nothing else, legalisation of cannabis would regulate the drug, allowing for safety through checks and make knowledge about population consumption more widely known. If alcohol can be legal, then so should cannabis.
